Context 

 
A. 
 
2. 
Sri  Lanka  is  at  a  critical  juncture  in  its  political  and  economic  history.  The  end  of  the 
armed  conflict  in  the  country’s  northern  region  in  mid-2009  and  the  presidential  election  held 
recently,  have  created  new  opportunities  for  social  and  economic  development  that  is  more 
equitable, sustainable, and people-centered. Periods immediately following conflict often shape 
the future of countries–and Sri Lanka is currently at this point. 
 
3. 
However, this optimism is tempered by several pressing realities, all of which impinge on 
the ability of the Government of Sri Lanka to respond to this historic opportunity. Until 2009, the 
lengthy conflict had seriously constrained the government’s efforts to enhance the quality of life 
and well-being of its citizens through sustained investments in the social sectors and to enhance 
the reach and depth of its social safety nets. As a consequence, the delivery of public services 
has  not  been  as  effective  as  it  could  have  been.  A  shallow  resource  base,  weak  systems  for 
public resource management, and, more recently, the global economic downturn that has hit Sri 
Lanka hard,1 have all combined to exacerbate inter- and intraregional disparities in the country. 
To  its  credit,  Sri  Lanka  has  fared  rather  well  in  terms  of  its  overall  achievements  in  economic 
and social development. It has maintained relatively high rates of social expenditure (during the 
1990s, it was more or less stable at 10% of the national budget) although resource allocation for 
the social sectors has tended to vary across provinces. 
 
While the economy has grown at an average of 5% over the past 30 years,2 the benefits

conflict-affected  areas  and  thus  employment  also  concentrated  in  geographical  pockets.  From

In  the  context  of  these  challenges,  the  government  needs  to  anchor  the  process  of 
empowerment of the people of the less developed regions in a strategic and phased approach. 
Efforts to increase investments in social and economic development can benefit from targeted 
financial assistance from donors and development partners, particularly to address emergency 
needs  and  short-term  investment  requirements  in  basic  services.  However,  sustainable 
investments are possible only through creation of greater fiscal space by instituting a strong and 
effective public resource management system.6  
 
7. 
Strengthening  the  public  resource  management  system,  particularly  in  a  post-conflict 
environment,  would  help  widen  the  fiscal  space  and  consequently  allow  for  targeted 
investments in social sectors for marginalized and vulnerable segments (see also Appendix 2). 
Any fiscal space enhancement at the center would provide greater resources at the disposal of 
the  government  for  the  provinces,  thus,  proportionately  increasing  allocations  for  the  lagging 
regions.  Since  the  allocative  efficiency  of  public  resources  is  constrained  by  weak  information 
gathering  and  sharing,  and  there  is  general  lack  of  sex-disaggregated  data  for  gender-
responsive targeting, investments in these areas will contribute to putting in place a more robust 
and efficient public resource management regime. More importantly, addressing these systemic 
and critical issues of public resource management would help achieve the broader objectives of 
stability,  peace,  and  national  reconciliation.  By  developing  capacity  to  arrive  at  improved 
targeting  of  social  expenditures—particularly  for  the  displaced  and  vulnerable  groups—a 
stronger public resource management system would help reduce regional disparities.

11. 
Strengthening  public  resource  management  for  sustainable  economic  and  social 
development. Sri Lanka is on track to achieve most of the Millennium Development Goals. The 
share of public investment in total government expenditure has increased from 19.6% in 2001 to 
25.4% in 2008 and also as a percent of GDP (increasing from 4.6% in 2002 to 6% in 2008). It 
also  has  a  relatively  extensive  social  protection  system  comprising  employment  protection, 
social  security  and  pensions,  and  social  safety  net  initiatives  that  include  cash  transfer 
schemes.  Allocations  for  welfare  programs  have  also  shown  a  steady  increase,  from  $302 
million  in  2006  to  $330  million  in  2009.  Notwithstanding  these  initiatives,  equity  and 
sustainability of these initiatives continue to face challenges. Access to social services and their 
quality remains an issue particularly for the rural poor whose children are more likely to suffer as 
a result (footnote 2). Government revenues, of which tax revenue constitutes 85%–90%, have 
been  sufficient  for  meeting  only  61%–72%  of  total  expenditures  in  the  past.  This  has  caused 
considerable  difficulties  for  achieving  greater  equity  in  social  sector  investments,  widening  the 
scope  of  the  social  safety  net,  and  sustaining  higher  social  expenditures  and  meeting  the 
additional need for post-conflict investments in Northern and Eastern provinces.  
 
12. 
The need to improve public resource management assumes greater urgency in view of 
the fact that the period for the rebuilding and economic regeneration activity—up to 2012 as per 
the Investment Program for the North (Waddakin Wassantham) and up to 2016 for the 10-year 
development framework—coincides with a period of escalated debt servicing requirements.11 To 
withstand these fiscal pressures, the fiscal space needs to be substantially enhanced.  
 
13. 
Three  issues  arise  from  the  analysis  of  the  political  economy  in  Sri  Lanka:  (i)  public 
investments need to be accelerated in order to improve economic and social infrastructure and 
ensure access to public services, especially in Northern and Eastern provinces; (ii) creation of 
sufficient  fiscal  space,  through  more  efficient  public  resource  management,  is  critical  for 
financing  higher  public  investments  and  sustaining  the  recurrent  cost  implications  of  such 
investments  (as  well  as  debt  servicing  requirements  of  the  borrowings  for  such  investments); 
and  (iii)  to  maximize  the  efficiency  of  public  investments  and  ensuring  proper  utilization  by 
minimizing leakages, it is necessary to put in place systems for effective fiduciary risk mitigation.

Output 2: More Efficient Expenditure Management  

 
The  current  expenditure  management  systems  are  marked  by  asymmetric  information 
38. 
flows  that  prevent  integrated  expenditure  management  and  provide  few  institutional  tools  for 
tracking. These deficiencies contribute to inadequate targeting of public expenditures and thus 
require redesign and re-engineering to enable for informed and timely decision-making on public 
investments.  Within  the  expenditure  management  system,  budget  preparation  and  execution, 
expenditure monitoring, account consolidation, and cash management, etc., are closely related 
activities  which  need  to  share  information  regularly  for  robust  financial  management. 
Implementation  of  an  integrated  treasury  management  information  system  (ITMIS)—an 
integrated  software  application  with  functionalities  catering  to  the  requirements  of  all  the 
departments  under  MOFP  will  (i)  lead  to  more  efficient  treasury  operations;  (ii)  enable  more 
informed  decision-making  on  allocation  and  use  of  public  resources  by  reducing  time  lags  in, 
raising  the  accuracy  of  budget  preparation,  execution,  and  evaluation;  and  (iii)  aid  in  better 
planning and targeting of operations and maintenance (O&M) expenditures for the new assets 
created through public investments. 
 
39. 
The ITMIS will cut across various functions of general treasury activities (Supplementary 
Appendix D): (i) budget preparation and commitment control (including allocations right down to 
the  spending  unit  level  as  well  as  imposing  containment  before  commitments  are  made);  (ii) 
payment  control  (which  minimizes  risk  of  mismanagement  of  funds  at  the  end-user  point);  (iii) 
cash  flow  management  (which  ensures  that  the  government  has  liquidity  to  execute  its 
payments  and  that  the  costs  of  this  liquidity  are  as  low  as  possible);  (iv)  debt  management 
(which is closely linked to cash and asset management, particularly for short-term and national 
debt);31 (v) fiscal planning and reporting (including, for example, online budgeting analysis with 
standard pre-defined reports [required as per the law], variable-based and query-based reports, 
etc.); and (vi) interfacing with RAMIS such that revenues are consolidated, accounted for, and 
reconciled on a more frequent basis.

budgeting using available sex-disaggregated data and targeted allocations to line ministries to

and  public  expenditure.  The  ITMIS  will  also  support  better  planning  of  needs-based  O&M 
expenditure for the assets created through the large investments.

To finance excess of expenditures over revenues, the government depends primarily on 
loans  (foreign  and  domestic)  and  on  grants.  The  share  of  grants  in  deficit  financing  has 
increased from 5.8% in 2003 to 11.0% in 2007, and the share of loans in deficit financing has

government  increased  at  an  annual  average  rate  of  12.7%  during  2003–2007,  while  GDP 
increased by 18.4% per annum during the same period. Higher economic growth, together with 
fiscal consolidation efforts, led to a declining debt–GDP ratio from 102.3% in 2003 to 81.1% in 
2008. The total debt of the government increased by SLRs536 billion between 2007 and 2008, 
and the external (public and private) debt–GDP ratio is estimated to have declined from 50.2% 
of GDP in 2006 to 43.5% in 2009 (although it is projected to increase to 47.3% of GDP in 2011, 
according to International Monetary Fund estimates). Also, high budgetary deficits have, in the 
past, required high domestic borrowing, which consequently increased the debt servicing costs 
for the government.

Fiscal Constraints and Issues 
 

15.   A key issue currently impairing the country's economy is the declining growth of revenue 
collection. The mobilization of tax revenue has been hit by the slowdown in economic activity. 
The growth of government revenues fell from 18.3% in 2007 to 16.0% in 2008. While the 2009 
budget  expected  a  revenue–GDP  ratio  of  16.4%,  it  has  been  revised  down  to  14.9%.  This 
implies an overall revenue shortfall of SLRs127 billion in 2008, compared to the budget target. 
Against the backdrop of the global crisis, enhancing tax buoyancy, broadening the tax base, and 
addressing administrative loopholes have become all the more urgent. This issue requires an in-
depth analysis of revenue policy structure and the administrative set-up, and significant revenue 
reforms.  

16.   Another  fiscal  constraint  being  faced  by  Sri  Lanka  is  the  increasing  volatility  of  the 
government’s  debt  portfolio.  The  government  has  been  increasingly  turning  to  foreign 
commercial borrowing in recent years, the share of which in total foreign debt has risen from 5% 
in 2003 to 11% in 2008. As the maturities of the commercial borrowings are relatively short, the 
rollover risk of this debt is high. In addition, given weaknesses in information sharing and other 
systemic  constraints  that  pose  difficulties  in  effective  debt  management,  the  government 
requires support in its debt management practices and system.

A.  Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
  
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy 2009–2011 for Sri Lanka,a approved in 2008, is aligned to 
the  government's  10-year  development  framework  2006–2016,  and  the  program  for  2009−2011  is  focused  on  the 
government's  priority  areas.  ADB’s  strategy  focuses  on  the  two  pillars  identified  in  the  framework:  (i)  strengthening  the 
investment climate, and (ii) achieving socially inclusive development. The first pillar deals with infrastructure development and 
human  resource  development  to  improve  competitiveness.  The  second  pillar  focuses  on  regional  disparities  and  looks  at 
development  of  infrastructure  and  administrative  and  absorptive  capacity  in  the  poorer  regions  to  improve  the  delivery  of 
public  services.  The  country  partnership  strategy  specifically  focuses  on  decentralizing  public  services  and  strengthening 
revenue collection by provinces. With the end of military operations in early 2009, new priorities have emerged for Sri Lanka. 
On the request of the government, ADB brought forward planned interventions in the north in the country operations business 
plan for 2010–2012,b and the 2010 pipeline is largely focused on the north.  
 
The Fiscal Management Efficiency Project (FMEP) has strong links to key goals in the 10-year development framework, which 
focuses  on  infrastructure  development  to  accelerate  growth  and  narrow  regional  disparities.  Randora,  the  government’s 
infrastructure  investment  plan,  looks  at  major  power,  highway,  port,  and  airport  development  projects.  Various  other 
programs,  such  as  Maga  Neguma,  look  at  rural  infrastructure  development.  These  programs  are  expected  to  improve 
connectivity  of  rural  areas  to  urban  centers  and  the  global  economy,  which  is  seen  as  a  key  factor  in  revitalizing  the  rural 
economy.  The  FMEP  aims  to  create  the  scope  for  greater  investments  by  strengthening  revenue  and  public  expenditure 
management. This will result in higher public investments in physical and social infrastructure.  
 
The 10-year development framework looks at improving the macroeconomic environment, in part by reducing the fiscal deficit 
to 5% by 2011, through substantially higher revenue collection. Increasing the tax revenue to gross domestic product ratio as 
a  result  of  efficient  revenue  administration  is  a  key  outcome  of  the  FMEP.  The  project  will  focus  on  improving  tax 
administration by supporting broad-based management information system reforms and expenditure prioritization and efficient 
expenditure  management  through  the  implementation  of  the  integrated  treasury  management  information  system  (ITMIS). 
These interventions will allow greater fiscal space for infrastructure development. 
 
With the ending of military operations in May 2009, reconstruction and development of the former conflict areas has become a 
priority for the government. While there are many post-war challenges, the government has developed the $2.68 billion 3-year 
development  plan  for  the  north,  based  on  the  experience  in  the  east,  where  major  military  operations  ended  in  2007.  The 
expenditure rationalization envisaged under the project will support allocation of expenditure into northern reconstruction for 
livelihood development and reconstruction of community infrastructure.

1.  Key Issues  
 
Sri Lanka is on track to achieve the first Millennium Development Goal (MDG) of halving poverty by 2015. The Head Count 
Index  reported  in  2006–2007  (15.2%)  is  nearing  the  50%  mark  (13.1%)  of  26.1%  reported  in  1990–1991.  The  rural  sector, 
where 80% of the population resides, is the main contributor to the drop in national poverty and where the poverty incidence 
dropped  from  24.7%  in  2002  to  15.7%  in  2007.  However,  poverty  in  the  estate  sector,  which  holds  about  5.5%  of  the 
population, has increased from 30% in 2002 to 32% in 2007. A continuous drop in poverty throughout the last two decades in 
the urban sector of Sri Lanka has been matched by the highly urbanized Western Province in  which more than 60% of the 
urban population of Sri Lanka lives. 
 
Sri  Lanka  has  fared  well  in  terms  of  nonincome  poverty  indicators.  The  country  is  an  early  achiever  with  regard  to  several 
MDG  indicators  relating  to  nonincome  dimensions  of  human  development,  such  as  universal  primary  school  enrollment, 
gender parity in primary and secondary school enrollment, under-5 child mortality and infant mortality, universal provision of 
reproductive health services, decline in prevalence of tuberculosis and death rates, and increased access to safe water and 
sanitation.  However,  national  figures  mask  considerable  gender-related,  sector,  and  regional  variation  in  terms  of  these 
indicators. 
 
Differential access to infrastructure has been the main driver of the increase in inequality and underlies much of the regional 
economic  inequality;  there  has  been  a  big  gap  between  the  Western  Province  and  the  rest  of  the  country.  The  Western 
Province accounts for half of the total output in the country, while all other provinces contribute 10% or less each. It also has 
the best access to business opportunities, while geographical isolation and high average travel time to Colombo seem to be 
most closely correlated with poverty in other provinces.

Sri Lanka ratified the Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1981, and the Optional 
Protocol  in  October  2002,  but  there  is  limited  progress  toward  gender  equality.  Sri  Lanka  is  ranked  104th  in  the  Human

Measure, with a value of 0.371. It has not achieved the second MDG of universal primary education but has virtually achieved 
the third goal—gender equality in participation in primary and secondary education.  
 
Despite  the  country's  low  maternal  mortality  rate  of  27  per  100,000  and  very  low  child  mortality  rate,  large  numbers  of 
people, especially women, and particularly those in rural (including plantation) areas and the conflict- and tsunami-affected 
regions,  are  among  the  poorest  and  most  marginalized  and  have  little  voice  in  governance  structures  at  national  level. 
Structural  changes  in  the  economy  have  led  to  a  decrease  in  the  percentage  of  women  in  the  agriculture,  fisheries,  and 
forestry sectors from 40.5% of female labor in 2002 to 34.5% in 2005, and an increase of women in the manufacturing sector 
from 23.7% to 26.7% in the same period. 
 
Women, in general, bear the brunt of work in maintaining families and managing households. During natural disasters and 
conflict situations they face severe challenges regarding food and nutrition needs and security of family and assets. Studies 
done  on  the  current  global  economic  crisis  indicate  that  large  numbers  of  women  will  become  unemployed,  face  job 
insecurity,  be  pushed  more  into  the  informal  sector,  and  have  enormous  difficulties  in  ensuring  the  basic  needs  of  their 
families  and  dependents,  especially  due  to  rising  food,  shelter,  and  transport  costs.  Women  migrant  workers  face 
retrenchment and more limited overseas employment opportunities. 
 
With the death, disappearance, and migration of male family members during the ethnic conflict, women have had to ensure 
family survival during displacement and in welfare camps for internally displaced persons, and they face similar challenges in 
the process of resettlement in their original habitats, following the end of the war.  
 
The 10-year development framework program (Mahinda Chintana), 2006−2016, has charted policy directions in all sectors 
and line ministries and offers some gender-related features for women's empowerment. The national machinery for women, 
i.e., the Ministry of Child Development and Women's Empowerment, established in 2005—includes the Women's Bureau, the 
National  Committee  on  Women,  the  Children's  Secretariat,  the  Department  of  Probation  and  Child  Care  Services,  and  the

RISK MITIGATION  

 
Risk 
Delays in constituting a full-time project team, or 
absence of a full-time project team, create an 
ownership problem for the project. 
 

 

Lack of understanding of the solution to be 
deployed at the beginning of the project may 
become a bottleneck. Major problems arise if the 
solution does not meet the expectation of the 
implementing agency fully and is discovered 
during project execution. 

Technology obsolescence of the solution offered 
normally has considerable impact on the solution 
deployment. 

Lack of clarity about the readiness of each 
stakeholder to perform his or her responsibilities 
results in slippage of project timeline. This is 
because, most of the time, the magnitude of 
responsibilities is understood only after the task 
has started. The project execution timeframes 
could be missed due to nonperformance of one 
stakeholder. 
Delays in policy-related decisions. During 
implementation of any IT solution, there will be 
need for some policy changes. In most cases, a 
clear procedure to address these kinds of 
requirements is not planned. Normally, policy-
related decisions take more time and result in 
project delays. 
Absence of a full-time technical team in place will 
dilute the whole purpose of the gap analysis.   
Risk of building existing inefficiencies into the 
system. 

Solution/Mitigation 
A dedicated full-time TA team is being proposed 
with clarity of roles and responsibility of each of 
the team members for the entire project duration. 
The team will work closely with the PMU with its 
office located at MOFP. 
There have been several detailed presentations 
on the RAMIS and PAFMIS under FMRP to 
senior officials as well as to the technical 
committee members. The PPTA consultants have 
also made presentations, and held discussions 
with key stakeholders, on the solution and there is 
unanimity in adopting a customized off-the-shelf 
solution. 
TA project management consultants will ensure 
that at the beginning of the project there is 
verification of the availability of the technology 
proposed by the vendor, and take necessary 
steps if the technology is not supported by 
technology provider in the medium-to long-term. 
The PPTA consultants have undertaken a study 
of all the tasks of stakeholders and their 
interdependencies. Critical activities have been 
identified and there is a commitment from the 
implementing departments to provide dedicated 
staff to the PMU. Some time provision has been 
kept for critical activities in the project 
implementation plan. 
The PSC will meet at least quarterly to ensure 
that project delays do not occur. The fact that the 
project is being owned by MOFP, whose 
leadership has shown a strong commitment, 
means this risk will be mitigated. 

The PMU is envisaged with representation from 
all the implementing agencies to mitigate this risk. 
TA consultancy has been proposed to support 
identification of process improvement and 
process re-engineering requirements.  
The site work has been initiated under the FMRP 
for the DIR and it is expected to mitigate this risk. 
ITMIS and RAMIS will have an interface, and 
planning for the interface provision has been 
ensured through a common TA project 
management team for both the systems. 

Non-readiness of implementation site at all 
locations. 
Lack of adequate interfacing between systems: 
The IT implementation activities planned 
concurrently by other government agencies that 
have links with the system development are not 
fully studied.
